metadata.title: Allocating job losses: the mass layoffs at the Swedish Tobacco Monopoly in 1921

relevance.topic: Mass layoffs and labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study is relevant as it examines the impact of technological change on labor displacement, specifically the introduction of cigar machines leading to mass layoffs at the Swedish Tobacco Monopoly.

design.sample_characteristics: Workers at Malmo Cigar Factory, predominantly female, under 25 years old

dependent_variables.displaced: The study does not specify the exact number of workers displaced but indicates significant layoffs in 1921.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: The study does not provide specific details on unemployment or underemployment post-layoffs.

text_fragments: The management's initial proposal was to cut at both ends of the age distribution by pensioning off old workers and laying off young workers.
The seniority principle was officially replaced by the need principle in October 1921.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the shift from seniority-based layoffs to a need-based approach due to technological changes and economic conditions.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The period was marked by a recession and declining consumer demand for cigars.
historical_context.institutional_context: The Swedish Tobacco Monopoly was a state-owned enterprise expected to balance profit maximization with social responsibility.

outcomes.main_findings: The introduction of cigar machines led to a shift from seniority-based layoffs to a need-based approach, with high-performing workers being protected.
outcomes.conclusions: Technological change led to the obsolescence of senior workers' skills, reducing their role in training processes and altering layoff criteria.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that the abandonment of the seniority principle had lasting effects on layoff practices in the industry.
